events.title: Birth
events.summary: Sergei Eduardovich Bortkiewicz was born in Kharkov, Russian Empire, to Polish noble parents Edward and Zofia Bortkiewicz. He spent his childhood on the family estate at Artiomovka, near Kharkov.
events.fun_version: Sergei Eduardovich Bortkiewicz was born in Kharkov, Russian Empire, to Polish noble parents Edward and Zofia Bortkiewicz. He spent his childhood on the family estate at Artiomovka, where 'royal' was just another day-at-home outfit, emphasizing the delightful but perhaps slightly absurd reality of noble life.

events.title: Music Training
events.summary: Bortkiewicz received his musical training at the Imperial Conservatory of Music in Saint Petersburg under notable teachers. He then traveled to Leipzig to further his studies at the Leipzig Conservatory and graduated with the Schumann Prize.
events.fun_version: Bortkiewicz received his musical training from the Imperial Conservatory of Music in Saint Petersburg, where notable teachers taught him everything except how to keep a straight face while playing the piano. After mastering the art of serious face-pulling, he decided to hit the road and traveled to Leipzig to pursue further studies. There, he graduated with the prestigious Schumann Prize from the Leipzig Conservatory, proudly adding it to his list of many musical accomplishments!

events.title: Marriage
events.summary: After completing his studies, Bortkiewicz returned to the Russian Empire in 1904 and married Elisabeth Geraklitowa, a friend of his sister, before settling in Berlin.
events.fun_version: Bortkiewicz completed his studies and returned to the Russian Empire in 1904, marrying Elisabeth Geraklitowa, a friend of his sister, before settling in Berlin.

events.title: Piano Concerto Premiere
events.summary: In November 1913, pianist Hugo van Dalen premiered Bortkiewicz's Piano Concerto No. 1 in Berlin, marking a significant achievement in the composer's early career.
events.fun_version: In November 1913, pianist Hugo van Dalen put on a show with Bortkiewicz's Piano Concerto No. 1 in Berlin, marking a significant achievement in the composer's early career. It was such an achievement that even the keys of the piano were sending him thank-you notes!

events.title: House Arrest and Deportation
events.summary: The outbreak of World War I led to Bortkiewicz and his wife being placed under house arrest and later deported back to Russia. This was a turning point in their lives.
events.fun_version: So, World War I busted out unexpectedly, and suddenly Bortkiewicz and his wife found themselves playing the not-so-fun game of 'house arrest.' Eventually, they were deported back to Russia. This unexpected turn of events certainly changed their lives, making it a life twist that could belong in a bad romcom!

events.title: Return to Kharkov
events.summary: After being deported, Bortkiewicz returned to Kharkov, where he established himself as a music teacher while giving concerts during the chaotic times of World War I.
events.fun_version: After being forcibly relocated like a misplaced sock, Bortkiewicz returned to Kharkov, where he decided to teach music and give concerts instead of managing a circus during the chaotic times of World War I.

events.title: Escape to Constantinople
events.summary: In November 1919, Bortkiewicz succeeded in escaping from Yalta to Constantinople with his wife, after suffering losses during the Russian Revolution.
events.fun_version: In November 1919, Bortkiewicz pulled off an escape so smooth it would make a magician jealous, fleeing Yalta for Constantinople with his wife. They left behind the chaos of the Russian Revolution.

events.title: Settling in Austria
events.summary: Bortkiewicz and his wife settled in Austria in July 1922 after a difficult journey through multiple countries as they sought a new home.
events.fun_version: Bortkiewicz and his wife finally plopped down in Austria in July 1922 after a difficult world tour that had more stops than a public bus, desperately seeking a new home.

events.title: Obtaining Citizenship
events.summary: In 1926, Bortkiewicz obtained Austrian citizenship, further establishing his residence and career in Vienna, where he lived peacefully until the rise of Nazi persecution.
events.fun_version: In 1926, Bortkiewicz decided that being a citizen of Austria would look fantastic on his resume. He settled in Vienna, enjoying the tranquil life until the rise of Nazi persecution disrupted his peaceful existence.

events.title: War Impact and Financial Struggles
events.summary: World War II severely impacted Bortkiewicz's finances and health, forcing him to teach under dire conditions while losing most of his income due to destruction of his musical works.
events.fun_version: World War II severely impacted Bortkiewicz's finances and health, forcing him to teach music under dire conditions while his income plummeted due to the destruction of his musical works.

events.title: Master Class Appointment
events.summary: In the autumn of 1945, Bortkiewicz was appointed director of a master class at the Vienna City Conservatory, providing him with some financial security after the war.
events.fun_version: In the autumn of 1945, Bortkiewicz was appointed director of a master class at the Vienna City Conservatory. That was a great gig! He finally had a steady paycheck after the war—turns out, teaching music is more lucrative than many imagined.

events.title: 75th Birthday Concert
events.summary: On 26 February 1952, Bortkiewicz celebrated his 75th birthday with a concert at the Musikverein in Vienna, conducting the orchestra for his works.
events.fun_version: On February 26, 1952, Bortkiewicz turned 75, and instead of blowing out candles, he decided to blow the roof off the Musikverein in Vienna with a concert! Imagine conducting an orchestra and thinking, 'This is how you throw a birthday bash — with a symphony instead of a cake!' He conducted the orchestra for his own works.

events.title: Death
events.summary: Bortkiewicz passed away on 25 October 1952 in Vienna after a surgery that he never recovered from, marking the end of his impactful life as a composer.
events.fun_version: Bortkiewicz passed away on October 25, 1952, in Vienna, after a surgery. He left behind an impactful legacy as a composer—a symphony, sometimes sweet, sometimes a total cacophony, but always unforgettable!
